Decoding India’s growth slowdown

Published: January 10, 2025 08:30 am IST

Source: The Hindu

The first advance estimate of India’s GDP for 2024-25 reveals a decline in real GDP growth rate to 6.4% from 8.2% in 2023-24, which challenges previous projections.   • India's GDP growth rate projected to decline significantly in 2024-25.
  • Concerns about the reliability of official GDP estimates due to data collection issues.
  • Private sector investment is not responding positively to government tax cuts, affecting overall economic growth.
  • Public spending remains crucial in sustaining economic growth amidst a slowdown.
  • The economic slowdown risks disrupting the Union Budget's fiscal targets.
“A reworking of the revenue mobilisation strategy is required to enhance capex and welfare spending.”

The analysis indicates the need for structural changes and improved data reliability to accurately reflect the economic landscape.

item.title: “Enough To Devastate Every U.S Navy Warship At Norfolk”: China’s “Shadow Fleet” Raises Alarm In Washington - EurAsian Times
item.description:
China's 'Shadow Fleet' Raises Alarm in Washington

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: EurAsian Times

The U.S. has blacklisted China's largest shipping company, Cosco Shipping Holdings Co., along with major shipbuilders for their alleged ties to the People’s Liberation Army (PLA), escalating geopolitical tensions.

  • Cosco Shipping is now listed on the U.S. Federal Register blacklist.
  • This blacklisting extends to major players in tech and energy sectors in China.
  • Past sanctions on Cosco included penalties for transporting Iranian oil.
  • The blacklisting serves as a deterrent to U.S. businesses from engaging with these companies.
  • Concerns are raised about China’s use of merchant ships to support military operations, namely the civil-military fusion strategy.
  • A notable incident involved the COSCO Sakura ship docking near the Norfolk Naval Station.
  • Experts warn about the potential of using commercial vessels for military logistics.
  • China's maritime militia strategy is drawing significant attention and concern.
“If only, say, 10% of those containers were used for munitions, they could, for example, field 144 cruise missiles and 252 quadcopters, more than enough to devastate every warship at Norfolk...” - Thomas Shugart

This situation highlights the implications of China's military shipping strategies and the ongoing U.S.-China maritime competition.

item.title: FIIs begin 2025 with $2 billion selloff in 7 days. 6 reasons driving the exodus - The Economic Times
item.description:
FIIs Begin 2025 with $2 Billion Selloff in 7 Days: 6 Reasons Driving the Exodus

Publication Date: January 8, 2025

Source: ETMarkets.com

Foreign institutional investors (FIIs) have sold nearly $2 billion worth of Indian stocks in the first seven trading days of 2025 due to multiple factors impacting market confidence.

  • Earnings Downgrades: India Inc is facing downgrades in earnings after years of robust growth.
  • Weaker Macroeconomics: The Indian GDP growth is projected to slow down significantly.
  • Record Low Rupee: The Indian rupee is at a lifetime low against the dollar, affecting FII confidence.
  • US Bond Yields: Rising US Treasury yields are diverting investments from India.
  • Tariff Fears: Uncertainty about US trade policies post-Trump's inauguration is causing apprehensions.
  • Competition from the US Market: The dominance of the US market is attracting global capital away from emerging markets.
This will have many ramifications for consumer and business confidence, wage growth, corporate revenues, consumption, investment, credit demand and, most importantly, the fiscal arithmetic. - Rahul Bajoria, BofA Securities India

In conclusion, the substantial selloff reflects concerns among foreign investors about the Indian market's immediate prospects and macroeconomic stability amidst global uncertainties.

item.title: Fastest growing and declining job roles by 2030 as per WEF, all you need to know - Hindustan Times
item.description:

Publication Date: Jan 10, 2025
Source: Hindustan Times

The World Economic Forum (WEF) has released the Future of Jobs Report 2025, highlighting significant changes in the global labor market by 2030.

  • 170 million new jobs will be created, with 92 million jobs displaced, leading to a net increase of 78 million jobs.
  • Big data specialists, FinTech engineers, and AI & machine learning specialists are predicted to be the fastest growing job roles.
  • The fastest declining roles include postal service clerks, bank tellers, and data entry clerks, primarily driven by technological advancements.
  • Farmworkers are expected to see a major increase, with 35 million more jobs anticipated by 2030 due to green transition trends.
“Farmworkers top the list of the largest growing job roles in the next five years…”

The report emphasizes the necessity of adapting to changing job landscapes and preparing for future opportunities in the workforce.
